DELEGATED MAINTENANCE AGREEMENT II WITH THE CITY AND COUNTY OF SAN FRANCISCO This DELEGATED MAINTENANCE AGREEMENT II ("AGREEMENT") is made by and between the State of Colifornia, acting by and through the Department of Transportation ("STATE") and the City and County of San Francisco /"LOCAL AGENCY"); each may be referred to individually as a "PARTY" and jointly as "PARTIES." RECITALS 1. This AGREEMENT will identify specific maintenance functions the LOCAL AGENCY will perform in the STATE right of way, including highway and freeway areas situated within STATE's jurisdictiond limits as authorized under Streets and Highways Code Section 114 and 116. 2. The PARlES executed a prior Delegated Maintenance Agreement dated 07/02/2009, which has been amended three times. This AGREEMENT does not supersede said Delegated Maintenance Agreement which will remain in full force and effect. This AGREEMENT does not supersede any Freeway Agreements or Maintenance Agreements executed by the PARTIES. OPERATIVE PROVISIONS I. Maintenance Services. LOCAL AGENCY shall perform maintenance operations as set forth in this AGREEMENT, at the State Route(s) identified in Exhibit A. Maintenance operations include the removal of: encampments, litter, debris, weeds. 2. Prior Delegated Maintenance Agreements. This AGREEMENT does not supersede the PARTIES' prior Delegated Maintenance Agreement/s), Freeway Agreements or Maintenance Agreements executed by the PARTIES. The previous agreements shall remain in full force and effect. Maintenance Standards. LOCAL AGENCY shall perform "maintenance" as defined in Streets and Highways Code Section 27 in compliance with the standards set forth in STATE policies, procedures, and specifications in effect and as amended. Notwithstanding the terms of this Agreement, LOCAL AGENCY's compliance with applicable municipal ordinances, procedures, and regulations shall be deemed to satisty the requirements of this Agreement as long as such municipal ordinances, procedures, and regulations are not in confict with and meet or exceed STATE laws, policies, procedures, and specifications and are not in conflict with and Reported with Solve SF.

text: Urgent Action Needed: Encampment at Mariposa St. / I-280 Off-Ramp Request for Targeted Removal and Follow-Through I write regarding your August 27, 2025 press release announcing that the City has entered a delegated maintenance agreement with Caltrans to address encampments on state rightofway, clean streets, and improve safety. This is a significant stepbut it appears the encampment adjacent to the I280 offramp at Mariposa Street (next to Pennsylvania Street Gardens) continues to pose serious public health, safety, and environmental concerns. This location has suffered from illegal dumping, fires, used needles, human waste, theft, and drug activity. Volunteers and community members have struggled under minimal city response. Therefore, I respectfully request: 1. Immediate mobilization of city outreach and cleanup teams, under the new Caltrans-city framework, to conduct a targeted removal of the encampment at this site. 2. Confirmation of which city department(s)e.g., Public Works, DPW, Homelessness & Supportive Housingare leading the effort, who the Caltrans-point counterparts are, and when removal will occur. 3. Post-action documentation, including safety mitigation, service connection outreach, hazardous debris removal, and ongoing maintenance scheduling. Given your public commitment to cleaning city streets in partnership with Caltrans, the community expects timely, visible action at this off-ramp. Please provide confirmation of next steps and operational timelinesideally within 7 business days. Thank you for aligning policy commitments with on-the-ground safety and equity.... text: Subject: Urgent Complaint: Homeless Encampment Blocking Emergency Exit at Betty Ann Ong Chinese Recreation Center (1199 Mason Street) Dear San Francisco Recreation & Parks Department, We are writing on behalf of the residents living next to the Chinese Recreation Center on Mason Street. For several years since the pandemic, multiple homeless individuals have been occupying the building’s emergency exit doorway facing Mason Street. Although Public Works occasionally removes their belongings during the day, these individuals always return after hours, especially in the evenings and on weekends, and continue to camp there. This has caused serious safety, sanitation, and security concerns, including:         • Repeated harassment and verbal threats toward nearby residents.         • Individuals carrying metal pipes and damaging nearby vehicles.         • Daily public urination/defecation in the alleyway, garage doorway and emergency exit.         • Continuous blocking of the emergency exit doorway facing Mason Street.         • Throwing away waste and food of all sizes anywhere seriously affects the public environment We strongly urge Rec & Parks to take permanent preventive measures such as fencing, gating, or other anti-trespassing solutions to secure this emergency exit area. This is not a one-time encampment issue but an ongoing and escalating safety hazard. Thank you for your prompt attention.
